documents.document: @Olivefarmer Exactly why engagement is needed asap. :)
@testeeves @sgalla32 They have all the best genomes. Some really fantastic genomes. We're going to do big things with those genomes. :)

@seanmhoban @brantfaircloth Sorry, to be clear, we did not multiplex our PCRs - just pooled for genotyping.
@seanmhoban @brantfaircloth 2/2 When designing pools, reduce overlap or use different M13 dyes for overlapping primers to avoid confusion.
@seanmhoban @brantfaircloth 1/2 PCR worked fine for us with M13. We pooled 4-5 primers for genotyping.
@seanmhoban @EEPuckett @quooddy @ware @catcullingham Can't help you there - we used to label our own with M13 during PCR to save $$.
Jstor is like my least favourite online publishing library - this would be a terrible date. Wiley and chill, now yo… https://t.co/1OguOfYLeO
What do you think about Birds NZ? Their survey closes at 5:30pm tomorrow. Speak now or forever hold your peace! Bir… https://t.co/Oi0Uo7w3Ck
@seanmhoban track changes can mess up line numbers so I normally highlight changes in grey and quote line nos. in the response.
Make sure you have your say on potential changes to Birds NZ. And be in to win some birding prizes while you're at… https://t.co/rIMZt9owJ4
@MicrobialMe @davidacoil @ScienceByDRE @watermicrobe @kylejbibby @mSphereJ Good idea. Sourcing reviewers seems a major problem for funders.
@MicrobialMe @davidacoil @ScienceByDRE @watermicrobe @kylejbibby @mSphereJ Saves time & makes sense. Don't understand why others don't do it
@ScienceByDRE @davidacoil @MicrobialMe @watermicrobe @kylejbibby @mSphereJ Has to have been rejected by "high profile journal" prior to ME
@ScienceByDRE @davidacoil @MicrobialMe @watermicrobe @kylejbibby @mSphereJ Molecular Ecology does, but only for "from the cover" submissions

Handy review on runs of homozygosity in livestock: https://t.co/jIw06XcJc6 I dream of the day we can use ROH in threatened species...
@t_buckley_nz Bit of a worry for making conservation management recommendations...
How do the bioinformatics tools used with RAD-seq/GBS data affect genetic inference? Quite a bit. A sobering read. 😳 https://t.co/WlOORWhM3I
NZ peeps - tell @OSNZBirdsNZ what you think of them and be in to win some sweet birding prizes. Constructive critic… https://t.co/lfKVvrZSmm
Stoked to get the new @Forest_and_Bird #BestFishGuide app. Download it now! Bad news for you, @JackHPascoe - all 3… https://t.co/cYVD8LiqI0
Big congrats to @SciEms and @Josie_Anya for taking out the student presentation prize and runner up award. Well deserved on both! #AWMS2016
Behrendorff: beached marine fauna = key food for dingoes. Managers need to drag carcass behind dunes so dingoes can eat in peace. #AWMS2016
Behrendorff: used camera traps to monitor dingoes at marine fauna carcasses. Theft of cameras = a real issue. 😔 #AWMS2016
Taking us into afternoon tea, Linda Behrendorff on dingoes foraging on marine animals washed up on Fraser Island (K… https://t.co/teGkNfEcQr
Thomas: kangaroos seem to have extremely high site fidelity. More data needed to confirm. #AWMS2016
Thomas: kangaroos are using urban, bush, and golf course areas. Potential problems with welfare, nuisance and disease. #AWMS2016
Now Georgia Thomas on GPS loggers for eastern grey kangaroos at the Nelson Bay golf course. Not popular with golfer… https://t.co/yfFDFBCIaw
Cooper: next step= GPS trackers to find out where the Tāwharanui little blue penguins are foraging. #AWMS2016
Cooper: sadly 7 little blue penguins have already been found dead - recently fledged chicks that have starved. #AWMS2016
Cooper: little blue penguins seem to be on the increase in Tāwharanui based on penguin burrows found. #AWMS2016
Now some info on the little blue penguin popularion at Tāwharanui from Kaya Cooper. #AWMS2016 https://t.co/wvaQDeEHk6
Whitehead: why does site affect HR in northern bettongs? Seems to be density dependent. #AWMS2016
Whitehead: Site and gender = main drivers of HR size in northern bettongs. Male HR =2× size of female. #AWMS2016
Tegan whitehead now telling us about home ranges in northern bettongs. #AWMS2016 https://t.co/1ZmnYPKoV8
I got applause for doing a talk about genetics with no genetic data in it. We must get better at presenting our data! @kyliesoanes #AWMS2016
Allen: in summary - extreme animal rights thinking could actually threaten conservation initiatives #AWMS2016 https://t.co/rdtuLAPUGW
Allen: if can't introduce dingoes to see what happens when they're there, have to shoot them to see effects when they're not. #AWMS2016
Allen: here's the legal issue - we're getting tangled in legislation designed to prevent cock-fighting etc...… https://t.co/MzdcanWSNv
Allen: the RSPCA stated using predators to control prey = cruel and the wrong attitude. Lead to government shutting project down. #AWMS2016
Allen: Pelorus Island is an ideal "lab" for assessing dingoes as pest controllers. But immediate public opposition… https://t.co/x91GKFdAtS
Allen: People these days tend to like large predators, especially if they live in cities and don't have anything to do with them 😊 #AWMS2016
Now Ben Allen tells us what can go wrong when we try and use top predators to control pest prey species. #AWMS2016
Drummond: of 109 juveniles banded in 2015-16 in Tawharanui, only 15 recruited. Not dispersing away - population should persist. #AWMS2016
Now a species close to my heart - Faline Drummond is talking about survival of cheeky North Island robins post rein… https://t.co/4n0K46mZ4W
Hampton: if don't improve welfare outcomes for shooting, risk being banned from using an already socially difficult technique. #AWMS2016
Hampton: straightforward to improve welfare outcomes -> look to testing of lethal traps in NZ for good examples of how to do this. #AWMS2016
Hampton: cautionary tale from Harp seals - same shooting methods used for juvs & adults. Many animals suffered poor welfare. #AWMS2016
Hampton: rapid advances in firearms technology are making it difficult for animal welfare guidelines to keep up. #AWMS2016
Now Jordan Hampton talks about the conflict between pest control and animal welfare. A tricky balance, especially for shooting. #AWMS2016
Weihong Ji: food given to snub-nosed monkeys for ecotourism is too high in carbs. Need higher quantities of other food groups. #AWMS2016
Weihong Ji: when we give animals food outside their normal nutrient balance, can cause changes to foraging and over consumption. #AWMS2016
Weihong Ji: golden snub-nosed monkey ecotourism involves supplemental feeding with corn, turnip, and fruits -> could cause issues. #AWMS2016
Something completely differnt for #AWMS2016 - Weihong Ji's work focuses on golden snub-nosed monkey - a species wi… https://t.co/HElU2CAy6s
Now Weihong Ji on the nutritional impacts of ecotourism on target animals - a study conducted in China. #AWMS2016
An overview of how feeding garden birds affects their disease infection rates - results = complex and mixed.… https://t.co/f6kWz5LWKl
Unexpected result - silver eyes not being fed had more endoparasites than those that were. Blackbirds show opposite. @Josie_Anya #AWMS2016
@Josie_Anya proving that garden birds are disgusting and you definitely don't want to get up close and personal wit… https://t.co/vOIc0MxoGf
It takes a lot of food to do a bird feeding study - 1500kg of bread and 1300kg of seed to be precise! Bread mountai… https://t.co/ZmFO9hwYXd
The awesome @Josie_Anya is now telling us about how bird feeding affects avian disease dynamics. #AWMS2016 https://t.co/v9m3nzwOya
Other very good reasons to eradicate introduced mammals if you're more commercially rather than conservation-minded. https://t.co/fefQWcoA0A
Williams: why we can't afford to ignore wallabies - predicted spread is 1/3 area of N and S islands in worst case s… https://t.co/C5i7iRJ01C
Williams: indicator dogs and camera trapping = promising new methods for wallaby detection. #AWMS2016
Williams: proof that wallabies are timid and possums are not...regardless of their personalities. 😂 #AWMS2016 https://t.co/fjbJG23fb3
Williams: unfortunately, public acceptance of pest control methods is inversely correlated with their efficacy. 1080 anyone? #AWMS2016
Williams: How low should we go? For wallabies, we don't know how low numbers have to be to reduce their impact on vegetation. #AWMS2016
And now an introduced NZ pest we don't often talk about - Dale Williams on Dama (or Tammar/silver grey/Kangaroo Is… https://t.co/ihSbv0jA1f
Now Charles Krebs on camera traps. Do we need to know absolute density and, if so, can we get this from camera trap data? #AWMS2016
Yet another problem with cats. Even if you don't care about native birds, how about livestock? #AWMS2016 https://t.co/VNgRQVNYdr
Great to see baseline monitoring in Cape to City pest eradication project from @AS_Glen. Can't judge success without baselines! #AWMS2016
@Di_GleesonNZ - Invasive Animals CRC is developing a real time in situ eDNA tool. Exciting stuff! #AWMS2016
@Di_GleesonNZ - team used eDNA to detect reproductive activity in Macquarie perch - totally novel - out soon in @MethodsEcolEvol #AWMS2016
@Di_GleesonNZ - happy to be back in NZ so she can say "fush" without Aussies taking the piss. 😁 🐟🐟🐟 #AWMS2016
Check out this paper from @Di_GleesonNZ and colleagues on aquatic eDNA: https://t.co/Mk6MguQeZ6 #AWMS2016
Back from lunch with the ever fabulous @Di_GleesonNZ on environmental DNA (eDNA) for aquatic species monitoring.… https://t.co/POWK7GwqLb
Cope: want to ensure contraception is reversible in devils, but reproductive window is short. Best to use for 2nd breeding season. #AWMS2016
Cope: seems like no effect of contraception on social structure in devils. Also doesn't cause excess weight in females. #AWMS2016
Cope: Contraception effective effective in the 1st season, but sample size in 2nd season not enough to check what happened next. #AWMS2016
Cope: project determining the duration of contaception efficacy in Tassie devils and whether there are any side effects. #AWMS2016
Taking us into lunch, Holly Cope explains how contraception can be a good idea in Tassie devil captive management. #AWMS2016
This is what a koala population explosion looks like. Bad news for native plants. #AWMS2016 https://t.co/L0oAjPkpEo
Molsher: koala monitoring in blue gum is challenging and requires new methods. Still looking for something suitable… https://t.co/nKZuxn2UBR
Who knew there was such an issue with koala pop explosions? Robyn Molsher now talking about koala impacts on Kangaroo Island. #AWMS2016
Engaging early and often = important for preventing over expansion of koalas decimating coastal manna gum habitat. @JackHPascoe #AWMS2016
Now @JackHPascoe on what to do when you have too many koalas. Featuring a picture of not a koala. :) #AWMS2016 https://t.co/UlUh9r2epm
If you're in Oz, download the @WomSAT app for iPhone or Android and get involved! @dasyuridae #AWMS2016
Old: Last survey of wombat mange = 1998. New data needed - that's where the @WomSAT #citizenscience tool comes in. #AWMS2016
